articles.headline: Colleges Are Failing in Graduation Rates
articles.snippet: Much of the American system of higher education is failing in its core mission of getting students to graduate, with only Italy ranking lower among rich countries.
articles.abstract: Much of the American system of higher education is failing in its core mission of getting students to graduate, with only Italy ranking lower among rich countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you were going to come up with a list of organizations whose failures had done the most damage to the American economy in recent years, you’d probably have to start with the Wall Street firms and regulatory agencies that brought us the financial crisis. From there, you might move on to Wall Street’s fellow bailout recipients in Detroit, the once-Big Three.

articles.headline: Driver Texting Now an Issue in the Back Seat
articles.snippet: Differences of opinion about distractions behind the wheel are creating disputes among family members and friends.
articles.abstract: Differences of opinion about distractions behind the wheel are creating disputes among family members and friends.
articles.lead_paragraph: After decades of marriage, Terry and Debbie Buchen learned to work through various marital issues. Then something new came between them  his cellphone.

articles.headline: As an Exotic Mortgage Resets, Payments Skyrocket
articles.snippet: Defaults linked to unconventional mortgages are expected to hamper the real estate recovery for years to come.
articles.abstract: Defaults linked to unconventional mortgages are expected to hamper the real estate recovery for years to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: Edward and Maria Moller are worried about losing their house  not now, but in 2013.

articles.headline: Pentagon Keeps Wary Watch as Troops Blog
articles.snippet: The military’s interactive Web presence has two sides: the Pentagon’s official outreach, and troops’ informal posts.
articles.abstract: The military’s interactive Web presence has two sides: the Pentagon’s official outreach, and troops’ informal posts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the course of 10 months in eastern Afghanistan, an Army specialist nicknamed Mud Puppy maintained a blog irreverently chronicling life at the front, from the terror of roadside bombs to the tyrannies of master sergeants.

articles.headline: Bank Firing of Counsel Is Examined
articles.snippet: Timothy J. Mayopoulos, Bank of America’s former general counsel, has refused to reveal certain specifics of disclosure decisions he weighed in on at the company.
articles.abstract: Timothy J. Mayopoulos, Bank of America’s former general counsel, has refused to reveal certain specifics of disclosure decisions he weighed in on at the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four days after Bank of America shareholders voted to approve a merger with Merrill Lynch, Timothy J. Mayopoulos, the bank’s general counsel, was summoned to an executive suite.

articles.headline: Marred Afghan Vote Leaves U.S. in a Delicate Spot
articles.snippet: Concerns over vote fraud are conflicting with an interest in maintaining relations with President Hamid Karzai.
articles.abstract: Concerns over vote fraud are conflicting with an interest in maintaining relations with President Hamid Karzai.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  On Monday, as the vote-counting in Afghanistan was nearing an end, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton was briefed by the American ambassador in Kabul, Karl W. Eikenberry. The same day, the ambassador delivered a blunt message to the front-runner, President Hamid Karzai: “Don’t declare victory.”
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Overspending on Debit Cards Is a Boon for Banks
articles.snippet: Banks have long pitched debit cards as a convenient and prudent way to buy, but a growing number now allow consumers to exceed their balances — for a price.
articles.abstract: Banks have long pitched debit cards as a convenient and prudent way to buy, but a growing number now allow consumers to exceed their balances — for a price.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Peter Means returned to graduate school after a career as a civil servant, he turned to a debit card to help him spend his money more carefully.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: Kraft Chief Has History of Success
articles.snippet: If the past is any indicator, Irene B. Rosenfeld, Kraft’s chief executive, is not likely to take Cadbury’s rejection as the final word.
articles.abstract: If the past is any indicator, Irene B. Rosenfeld, Kraft’s chief executive, is not likely to take Cadbury’s rejection as the final word.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Irene B. Rosenfeld, the chief executive of Kraft, was studying marketing at Cornell in the late 1970s, she was determined to get as many people as possible to respond to a survey she mailed out as part of her Ph.D. research on how consumers choose products.

articles.headline: To Attract a Buyer, Make the Deal Irresistible
articles.snippet: Even the most frugal shoppers are being tempted by the blockbuster deals some retailers are offering.
articles.abstract: Even the most frugal shoppers are being tempted by the blockbuster deals some retailers are offering.
articles.lead_paragraph: Given the relentlessly dismal retail sales numbers, consumers seem to have locked away their wallets and hid the key.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Stephanie Rosenbloom

articles.headline: Seized Times Reporter Is Freed in Afghan Raid That Kills Aide
articles.snippet: Stephen Farrell, held captive by militants for four days, was freed in a military commando raid early Wednesday, but his Afghan interpreter was killed.
articles.abstract: Stephen Farrell, held captive by militants for four days, was freed in a military commando raid early Wednesday, but his Afghan interpreter was killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stephen Farrell, a New York Times reporter held captive by militants in northern Afghanistan, was freed in a military commando raid early Wednesday, but his Afghan interpreter was killed during the rescue effort.

articles.headline: As Menace to Hostages Grew, British Moved In
articles.snippet: Britain feared the Taliban would move the Times reporter and his Afghan interpreter to Pakistan, an official said.
articles.abstract: Britain feared the Taliban would move the Times reporter and his Afghan interpreter to Pakistan, an official said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Britain ordered a predawn commando raid in northern Afghanistan on Wednesday to rescue a British reporter for The New York Times and his Afghan interpreter after Afghan agents learned that the Taliban was planning to move the hostages into Pakistan, a senior Afghan official said Wednesday.
